description: From Latin mittimus (the opening word of such a document), first-person plural of mittō (“send”).

entries.meaning: (law, archaic outside the US) A warrant issued for someone to be taken into custody.
A writ for moving records from one court to another.
examples: Next, sometimes the same clerk, but often a second clerk, who may not have been in the courtroom, types up the mittimus, the formal court order that directs corrections offers[sic] to commit someone to prison, and something could get lost in translation there.

entries.meaning: A formal dismissal from a situation.
